stem: Based on the findings, which action should the nurse take FIRST?

options.text: Administer oxygen via non-rebreather mask at 15 L/min.
Document the presence of petechiae on the patient's chest and axillae.
Notify the orthopedic surgeon about the patient's change in condition.
Increase the intravenous fluid infusion rate to 200 mL/hr.

tabs.name: SBAR
tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: S: 72-year-old male, post ORIF (open reduction internal fixation) of a fractured femur following a fall 24 hours ago. Patient reports increased shortness of breath and chest pain. B: Patient has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. Surgery was uneventful. Pain controlled with IV morphine PCA. Ambulating with physical therapy this morning. A: Patient is now restless, with increased respiratory rate (32 breaths/min), SpO2 88% on room air. Auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing. New onset petechial rash noted on chest and axillae. Vitals: HR 110, BP 100/60, Temp 37.2°C (99°F). Patient is increasingly anxious. R: Suspect possible fat embolism. Request immediate evaluation and orders for respiratory support and further management. At 14:15, the patient's SpO2 dropped to 82%. Patient is now confused.

tabs.name: Vitals
tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
14:00: HR 110, BP 100/60, RR 32, SpO2 88% on room air, Temp 37.2°C (99°F)
13:00: HR 92, BP 120/70, RR 20, SpO2 95% on room air, Temp 37.0°C (98.6°F)

tabs.name: Physical Exam
tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: Neuro: Restless, confused. Cardiovascular: HR 110, BP 100/60. Respiratory: RR 32, labored breathing, diffuse wheezing, SpO2 88% on room air. Petechial rash noted on chest and axillae. Skin: Warm, diaphoretic.

tabs.name: Care Plan
tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Post-operative care following ORIF of femur fracture. Goals include pain management, prevention of complications, and promotion of mobility.

tabs.name: MAR
tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Morphine PCA, PRN for pain. Ondansetron, PRN for nausea.

rationale.correct: The patient's presentation (shortness of breath, chest pain, hypoxia, petechial rash, and confusion) strongly suggests a fat embolism. The immediate priority is to improve oxygenation. Administering high-flow oxygen via a non-rebreather mask is the most rapid way to increase the patient's SpO2 and address the hypoxia caused by the fat emboli obstructing pulmonary capillaries. This intervention directly targets the most life-threatening aspect of the situation.
rationale.incorrect: Documenting the rash, while important, does not address the immediate threat of hypoxia. Notifying the surgeon is necessary, but only after ensuring the patient is stable and receiving adequate oxygenation. Increasing IV fluids might be considered later to support blood pressure, but it will not address the primary problem of impaired gas exchange and could potentially worsen pulmonary edema if the patient has underlying cardiac issues.

answerBreakdown.analysis: Correct. Addresses the immediate life-threatening hypoxia.
Incorrect. Documentation is secondary to immediate intervention.
Incorrect. Notification is important but follows immediate stabilization.
Incorrect. Fluid bolus inappropriate with respiratory distress.

clinicalPearls: Fat embolism syndrome (FES) typically presents 24-72 hours after a long bone fracture.
The classic triad of FES includes respiratory distress, neurological symptoms (confusion, altered mental status), and petechial rash.
Early recognition and aggressive respiratory support are crucial in managing FES.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap is focusing on the notification of the surgeon or documenting the rash, both of which are important but not the immediate priority.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and prioritize interventions that directly address the patient's most critical physiological needs, which in this case is hypoxia.

mnemonic.title: FES Mnemonic
mnemonic.expansion: Fat Embolism Syndrome: Fever, Emboli (respiratory distress), Skin (petechiae)
